conclusion: Determine the height \( h_a \) from which the ball is released so it can just fly out from point \( D \).
Use principles of energy conservation and kinematics to find the required height.
At point \( D \), the ball just flies out, meaning the normal force from the track is zero.
The only force acting on the ball is the gravitational force, which provides the centripetal force required for circular motion.
The centripetal force is given by \( F_c = \frac{mv^2}{R} \).
The gravitational force acting downward is \( mg \).
Since the ball is at the top of the semicircle, the gravitational force provides the centripetal force: \( mg = \frac{mv^2}{R} \).
Solving for \( v \): \( v^2 = gR \).
Calculate \( v = \sqrt{gR} \).
Substitute \( g = 10 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) and \( R = 0.5 \, \text{m} \) to find \( v = \sqrt{5} \, \text{m/s} \).
The total mechanical energy at point \( A \) is converted into kinetic energy at point \( D \).
The potential energy at point \( A \) is \( mgh_a \).
The kinetic energy at point \( D \) is \( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).
Using energy conservation: \( mgh_a = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \).
Substitute \( v = \sqrt{5} \, \text{m/s} \) into the energy equation.
Calculate \( mgh_a = \frac{1}{2}m \times 5 \).
Simplify to \( mgh_a = \frac{5}{2}m \).
Solve for \( h_a \): \( h_a = \frac{5}{2g} \).
Calculate \( h_a = \frac{5}{2 \times 10} \).
Simplify to \( h_a = \frac{5}{20} \).
